Fair point, I can understand why my statement might come off as arrogant, I'm not saying I'm zero waste or that I'm an environmentalist. I'm just trying to stress that being vegan or at least making an effort to eat less animal products is the biggest thing you can offer to the environment.

I never said veganism is cruelty-free. The tops and trousers you are wearing are probably made in sweatshops in Vietnam. Many people who work in the animal agriculture industry suffer from PTSD. No one is perfect, but giving as much as you can is better than being completely careless.

No, a teacher is nothing like a boss or an employer. A teacher is supposed to guide students towards their success, to some extent at least.

There's a fine line between creating a difficult environment in order to prepare them mentally for the outside world (which I agree with) and simply being disrespectful. Besides, creating that environment for them is one technique that might help them succeed later in life so your statement is rather contradictive here.
That's mainly because previous generations were constantly told to suppress their feelings and stop complaining. Some students are more sensitive than others and that's okay.

That's what I'm implying though, a sense of mutual respect. Just as those actions would be considered disrespectful if they came from a student they're just as disrespectful deriving from a teacher. Because if a teacher is being disrespectful, then they give the impression that once you're an employable adult you have the authority to be as disrespectful as you please and getting away with it.

You're clearly missing my point. I never said it's okay to let students off everytime they're late or chit chatting in class, I'm just saying that it's contradictive to expect to be respected if you're doing the exact same shit and getting away with it every time.

I was just curious to see the responses of my post because I've been reading on child behaviour as I'm training to be a teacher and I'm honestly not surprised by the amount of "mature" people who were constantly told to suppress their feelings for years who now think that it's childish behaviour to call out people above their age on their mistakes.

WRITING.TITLE: Saying "no offence but ___" is actually quite considerate and initiates politeness.
WRITING.TEXT: Whenever someone says "no offense but ___" before saying something that they think might appear offensive to others is not as rude as carelessly saying their opinion because that shows that they establish that their intention is not to offend anyone but simply say their opinion. I feel like Covid-19 is lately more about government control rather than it being an actual virus. Seeing that the mortality rate was proven to be extremely low, the restrictions keep getting stricter and stricter, where I'm from at least. My country is in the Middle East and had 21 deaths in total. Lately, there was a slight rise in cases (95% asymptomatic, from random testing) and testing has become essential in airports (+ it is ridiculously expensive). Also, you're not allowed to dance in bars, or else there's an #8364;8000 fine, you're not allowed to go anywhere publicly (except bars/restaurants) without a mask or else there's a #8364;300 fine and bars cannot be open after 3 AM. I don't know, there's something off about this whole situation. I feel like the government has taken advantage of the situation and doesn't treat it like a virus anymore but a way to profit from it.

If you want to hunt on your free time, fine. You're trying too hard to prove to others and probably yourself that it's ethical and that you're also doing the animals a favour, it's pathetic and obviously a cope mechanism to feel better about yourself. If you're careless enough that you're killing innocent animals in their natural habitat you should also be careless enough to accept that it's completely unethical because all animals deserve to live. 1. That doesn't justify it in ANY way, murder is unethical whether it's a slow or quick death. You're not a predator and this is not your natural habitat. I'd accept the fact that hunters are predators if they could kill the prey with their own hands and eat it right there and then, they can't. 2. It's really hard to distinguish a female from a male prey within a shooting distance, if you get too close they'll probably get scared and run off. But still, murder is murder. Again you're trying too hard to prove that you're considerate of the prey, you're not. 3. Humans are not part of the same ecosystem as animals, so if humans stopped eating animals, the circle of life within the ecosystem of the animals wouldn't collapse in any way. You can provide food for yourself and your family from your local supermarket. In regards to animals and animal products, yes they're pumped up with hormones, anti-biotics and recycled vitamins/proteins, so you can just alrernatively try and thrive a plant-based balanced diet.

WRITING.TITLE: Complimenting strangers should be normalised.
WRITING.TEXT: As an extrovert, I love chit chatting to strangers in public spaces. Whenever I compliment someone, their reaction is heartwarming. You can instantly tell that their mood is lightened and it feels nice to know that you've made someone's day better. Of course, the approach matters. We live in a rather introverted society where some people are more reserved than others. When the approach is appropriate and it's not a catcalling scenario then anyone would appreciate a compliment as sometimes it can mean a lot. :)
Hence why I posted on this subreddit and the reason I believe that our society is more introverted than extroverted. It sucks I know :/
